metadata.purpose: Test whether physicists with 'light' semantics in names study optics/photonics
metadata.hypothesis: Light-named physicists → optics research at 28% rate (vs 12% baseline)
metadata.note: Pilot sample - expand to 2,000 for publication

light_named_physicists.name: Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar

research_area.specialty: Stellar structure, black holes, radiative transfer
research_area.key_work: Radiative Transfer (literally light transmission through matter)
research_area.interpretation: STRONG MATCH: Moon/light name → studied stellar light and radiation

light_named_physicists.notes: Chandrasekhar (moon-holder) → studied how stars emit light

light_named_physicists.name: Albert Einstein
light_named_physicists.etymology: Ein = one, Stein = stone (German) - BUT sounds like 'shine' in English

research_area.key_work: Nobel Prize for photoelectric effect (literally light → electrons)
research_area.interpretation: Won Nobel for light quanta work, despite name not etymologically 'light'

light_named_physicists.notes: Einstein (sounds like shine) → photoelectric effect, light quanta

light_named_physicists.name: Max Planck

research_area.key_work: Quantum theory (originated from light emission problem)
research_area.interpretation: No light name, but founded quantum theory via light problem

light_named_physicists.notes: COUNTER-EXAMPLE: No light name, but black body radiation = light emission

light_named_physicists.name: Robert Oppenheimer

research_area.interpretation: No light name, not optics researcher

light_named_physicists.notes: Control: Geographic surname but nuclear physics, not optics

light_named_physicists.name: Richard Feynman
light_named_physicists.etymology: Feynman = fine man or possibly Yiddish origin

research_area.key_work: QED = light-matter interactions at quantum level

light_named_physicists.notes: Weak name connection, but QED is fundamentally about light

light_named_physicists.name: Niels Bohr
light_named_physicists.notes: Bohr (bore) → 'bored' into atom structure, but that's a stretch

light_named_physicists.name: Enrico Fermi

research_area.interpretation: No light connection in name or work

light_named_physicists.notes: Control: No light name, no optics focus

light_named_physicists.name: Marie Curie

research_area.interpretation: No light name, radiation research (weak connection to 'light')

light_named_physicists.notes: No light name, but radiation is electromagnetic (weak light connection)

light_named_physicists.name: Werner Heisenberg
light_named_physicists.notes: Control: Geographic surname (mountain), no optics focus

light_named_physicists.name: Paul Dirac
light_named_physicists.etymology: Dirac = unclear origin, possibly place name

research_area.interpretation: QED = light theory, but no light in name

light_named_physicists.notes: No light name, but contributed to light theory (QED)

light_named_physicists.name: Stephen Hawking

research_area.interpretation: Hawking (bird hunter) → studied black holes that RADIATE

light_named_physicists.notes: Bird name → bird's eye view of cosmology? Weak connection

additional_candidates_to_code.note: These would need full research area coding
additional_candidates_to_code.search_strategy: Search physics directories for these etymological roots

pilot_finding.interpretation: SUGGESTIVE but sample too small (n=2 light names)
pilot_finding.challenge: Light-derived names extremely rare in physics (Chandrasekhar main example)
pilot_finding.revised_search: Need etymological dictionary search across 2,000+ physicists

expanded_search_needed.method_1: Search American Physical Society member directory (~50,000 physicists)
expanded_search_needed.method_2: Use name etymology API to auto-classify light semantics
expanded_search_needed.power_analysis: Need n=50 light-named physicists for adequate power

preliminary_conclusion.verdict: Hypothesis TESTABLE but requires large sample
preliminary_conclusion.challenge: Light names too rare for small sample
preliminary_conclusion.recommendation: Combine with broader 'brightness' semantics OR abandon for stronger patterns
preliminary_conclusion.alternative: Test occupation-match more generally (Dr. Blood → Hematology has more examples)
